No executable code, scripts, network operations, file system access beyond own content, or environment variable access. All static findings are false positives triggered by documentation patterns: bash command examples in Claude Code syntax (!`), mentions of security concepts (credentials, crypto), and URLs in documentation. Previous audit on 2026-01-07 confirmed safe status.

content.value_statement: Users need guidance to create reusable slash commands that standardize workflows across their team. This skill provides comprehensive documentation on command structure, YAML frontmatter, dynamic arguments, and bash execution patterns.
actual_capabilities: Create slash commands with Markdown file format and YAML frontmatter configuration
Define dynamic arguments using positional parameters $1, $2, $3 and $ARGUMENTS
Reference files in commands using @ syntax for file content inclusion
Execute bash commands inline with backtick syntax for dynamic context
Organize commands with namespacing and subdirectory structures
Use plugin-specific features like CLAUDE_PLUGIN_ROOT for portable paths
limitations: Provides documentation and guidance only - does not execute or install commands
Commands are text-based prompts, not executable scripts
Requires Claude Code environment to invoke commands
Does not modify system files or project configurations

use_cases.title: Standardize team workflows
use_cases.description: Create reusable slash commands that enforce consistent code review, testing, and deployment processes across team members.

use_cases.title: Build plugin commands
use_cases.description: Develop plugin-bundled commands using CLAUDE_PLUGIN_ROOT for portable path references and plugin resource access.

use_cases.title: Automate repetitive tasks
use_cases.description: Create commands with dynamic arguments and bash execution to automate common development tasks like git operations and testing.

output_examples.input: How do I create a slash command with arguments?
output: Slash commands are Markdown files with optional YAML frontmatter.
Place commands in .claude/commands/ directory with .md extension.
Use argument-hint to document expected arguments.
Reference arguments with $1, $2, $3 or $ARGUMENTS for all args.

output_examples.input: What is the difference between $ARGUMENTS and $1?
output: $ARGUMENTS captures all arguments as a single string.
Use $1 for first arg, $2 for second, and so on.
Use $ARGUMENTS when you need the entire input as one string.

output_examples.input: How do I restrict what tools a command can use?
output: Add allowed-tools field in YAML frontmatter.
Specify individual tools like Read, Write, Bash(git:*).
Use wildcards sparingly - prefer specific tool lists.

best_practices: Keep commands focused on single tasks - one command, one clear purpose
Use clear descriptions under 60 characters for /help display clarity
Restrict allowed-tools to only what the command actually needs
Document arguments with argument-hint for better discoverability
anti_patterns: Writing commands as messages to users instead of instructions for Claude
Using overly generic names that conflict with common command names
Omitting argument-hint when commands accept parameters
Granting excessive tool permissions in allowed-tools field

faq.question: Where do I save slash commands?
faq.answer: Project commands go in .claude/commands/, personal commands in ~/.claude/commands/, and plugin commands in plugin-name/commands/.

faq.question: What file format do commands use?
faq.answer: Commands are Markdown files with .md extension. Optional YAML frontmatter at the top configures description, arguments, and tool permissions.

faq.question: How do commands access files?
faq.answer: Use @ syntax to include file contents directly in commands, like @src/api.ts. The Read tool must be in allowed-tools.

faq.question: Are commands safe to use?
faq.answer: Commands only execute when you invoke them. Tool access is controlled by allowed-tools field. Review commands before first use.

faq.question: Why are my arguments not working?
faq.answer: Check that you use correct syntax: $1, $2, $3 for positional args or $ARGUMENTS for all args. Verify argument-hint matches usage.

faq.question: How do commands differ from agents?
faq.answer: Commands are lightweight prompts for quick tasks, agents are specialized AI for complex multi-step workflows. Commands are simpler and faster to create.
